metadata.title: Bell OH-58 Kiowa
aws::graph::propositions: The OH-58A Kiowa is a four-place observation helicopter.
The OH-58A Kiowa has two-place pilot seating.
The controls in the left seat of the OH-58A Kiowa are designed to be removed to carry a passenger up front.
During the OH-58A Kiowa's development for Vietnam War, it was fitted with the M134 Minigun.
The M134 Minigun is a 7.62 millimetres electrically operated machine gun.
The Australian Army leased eight OH-58As in 1971 in South Vietnam for eight months.
The Australian government procured the OH-58A for the Australian Army.
The Australian government procured the OH-58A for the Royal Australian Navy.
The OH-58A was designated as the CAC CA-32 in Australian service.
The CAC CA-32 was licensed produced in Australia by Commonwealth Aircraft Corporation.
The CAC CA-32 was the equivalent of the 206B-1.
The 206B-1 had an uprated engine and longer rotor blades.
The first twelve of 56 CAC CA-32 helicopters were built in the United States.
The twelve CAC CA-32 helicopters built in the United States were partially disassembled and shipped to Australia.
The twelve CAC CA-32 helicopters were reassembled in Australia.

text:
### OH-58A

The OH-58A Kiowa is a four-place observation helicopter. It has two-place pilot seating, although the controls in the left seat are designed to be removed to carry a passenger up front. During its development for Vietnam War, it was fitted with the M134 Minigun, a 7.62 millimetres (0.300 in) electrically operated machine gun.
The Australian Army leased eight OH-58As in 1971 in South Vietnam for eight months. The Australian government procured the OH-58A for the Australian Army and Royal Australian Navy as the CAC CA-32. Licensed produced in Australia by Commonwealth Aircraft Corporation, the CA-32 was the equivalent of the 206B-1 (uprated engine and longer rotor blades). The first twelve of 56 were built in the U.S. then partially disassembled and shipped to Australia, where they were reassembled.
